vclaim: "No cases of any child born alive after an abortion in Texas have been reported"
date: stated on April 16, 2019 in the Texas House:
title: The birth of a live child was not reported after an abortion in Texas
text: After the Republican leadership in Congress, Texas legislators look forward to civil sanctions for doctors who do not provide medical care in cases where a child is born alive after an attempted abortion. On Wednesday, legislators in the Council of State gave preliminary approval to the legislation by voting 93-1, with 50 Democrats registered as "appearants, not voting" in protest against the bill. The Texas Senate passed a similar bill last week. Donna Howard, Da-Osten, criticized what she called "a false, inflammatory and dangerous bill." "No cases of any child born alive after an abortion in Texas were reported," she said from the floor of the house. The proponents of the proposal argue that it is necessary and that, in rare cases, infants survive attempts at abortion. So is Howard right? The State data supported Howard Jacob Kotingham, Chief of Staff of Howard, and she said that her statement was based on data available through the Texas Health and Humanitarian Services Commission, which followed various abortion statistics. Health-care providers performing abortions since 2013 have been asked to provide data to the Committee on complications, including on infants born alive after attempted abortions. This was not reported in Texas between 2013 and 2016, the latest year in which publicly available data are available. The data include information on the complications that occurred during the abortion procedures of residents of Texas, including those that occurred outside the state. However, these complexities are determined not on an individual basis, but only in bulk. From 2013 to 2016, the number of unspecified complications faced by the people of Texas during abortions in other states ranged from 417 to 1,347 each year. Howard's claim was that there were reported cases of infants born alive after attempts to abort in Texas, so we did not go into these numbers. How can a child be born alive after an abortion? The Texas Act currently details "the rights of a live child after abortion or early birth" in the Act, providing that any child in this category "is entitled to the same rights, powers and privileges as the laws of this State grant to any other child born alive after the normal period of pregnancy." Under the law, a child is considered to be "living born" if he or she is removed from his or her mother after an attempt to abort and then breathe or show other life signs, including heartbeat, umbilical cord pulse or "volunteive muscle movement indefinitely." The legislation against which Howard spoke will establish a "doctor-patient relationship" between the child and the doctor who attempted to have an abortion and will allow the parents to sue the doctor. In one interview on January 31, 2021, John Kerry said that Hurricane Harvey "more water fell in Houston in five days than in Niagara Falls in one year." "In addition, the idea that doctors deliver, then kill or neglect treatment, a viable embryo is unfounded and dangerous information," was written. The proposed bill does not limit the protection on the basis of the child's childbearing age upon abortion, and requires doctors to provide the same care as "any other child born alive at the same age of pregnancy." Most abortions are performed in Texas before the foetus is considered viable, or able to remain outside the womb. There are different medical opinions from cases where the foetus reaches this critical threshold of 24 to 28 weeks after vaccination. Texas prohibits abortion after 20 weeks, unless the mother's life is in danger or there is serious abnormality in the foetus. At the national level, less than 1.3 per cent of the 638,169 abortions performed in 2015 occurred after 21 weeks, according to the Centre for Disease Control. There is little data at the national level, little empirical evidence of live birth after attempted abortion, and there is no consistent national data on this situation. A report from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention examined infant death certificates from 2003 to 2014, identifying 143 infants born alive after an attempt to abort and died shortly thereafter. This is not the total number of infants born after an attempt to abort, only those who died after giving birth. The CDC points out that this number could be too low, given that the Agency was trying to identify post-termination deaths (abortion) induced in return for automatic termination (abortion) and in some cases the language describing the situation was unclear. Of these 143 cases, 97 involved "matrimonial complications or, one or more congenital anomalies." To put this number in context: During the same 12-year period, more than 9.3 million abortions were performed in the United States. Our verdict, Howard, said, "No cases of any child born alive after an abortion in Texas have been reported." Health-care providers had to start reporting to the State in 2013 on complications arising from abortion procedures. We cannot know for sure whether any child was born alive after an abortion before 2013, but Howard ' s claim is limited to reported cases. Since the service providers had to start reporting the incident, there were no cases. We're assessing this claim right. The truth is - the statement is accurate and nothing important is missing.
